Senate vote on spending $100,000 of surplus to construct Hotung patio. Ups and downs [women's track] at the New Englands. [men's track] Jumbos plagued with injuries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Asian economic crisis meeting held. Custodians to file lawsuit. President of feminist Majority addresses prospects for future. This year's EPIIC [Education for Public Inquiry and International Citizenship] symposium praised by UN [United Nations] high commisioner for refugees. It's Chai time for Hillel. Chacana teachers to speak about release on monday. TCIA [Tufts Council of International Affairs] continues to build presence. Harvard professor [Stephen Jay Gould] lectures on the millenium. Seniors go out with a bang. [men's basketball]. Women [swimming] end with a solid season. Jumbos over-rule Judges with [men's basketball] win.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Senator optimistic after climate forum. Tufts to construct 40-story building in downtown Boston. Speakers deal with Migration in China. Panelists engage in a heated discussion. Refugee workers the topic of EPIIC [Education for Public Inquiry and International Citizenship] panel. Tufts Symphony Orchestra to perform tonight at Goddard. White Mules trample Jumbos [women's basketball]. A bittersweet ending for Sarah Howard.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Coalition to increase social justice solidarity. [women's track] ECAC's [Eastern College Athletic Conference] on the horizon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dinner addresses Tufts as a business. Medical School receives $10 million anonymous donation. $1 million earmarked for new renovations. Source and Senate to do battle. Memorial to junior Joseph Gonzales. Jumbos achieve first [women's basketball] winning season since 1994. Small conference tourneys are showing championship fervor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Housing Lottery Currently underway. D'Alarcao chosen as new chemistry chair. Date Rape Seminar to be held tonight.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Senate votes to lesson 'Source' punishment. Award to human rights activist [Matthew Lorin]. Senate apporves patio funding. Tough Schedule, injuries slowed Jumbos in quest [men's basketball].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Speaker [Katie Koestner] addresses date rape. Tufts to host LGB [Lesbian, Gay, and Bisexual] conference. Computer glitch delays lottery numbers. Senior wants to design toys. A life of brotherhood, service, and scholarship for a senior. Symphony plays the heartstrings. Free concert tonight raises awareness for human rights. Jumbos look to defend their two time ECAC [Eastern College Athletic Conference] [baseball] championships.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: DiBiaggio discusses campus issues in press conference. Jumbos finish [women's] winter [track] off strong.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: North Korean Famine topic of Wednesday evening forum. Email harassment difficult to prevent. Alpha Rho Lambda values role of community service. TUBEC welcomes new students to join group. Jumbos [men's lacrosse] look to improve. [women's lacrosse] Looking for young talent to replace lost experience. Softball team looks to return to NCAAs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lincoln-Filene Center under Badi Foster's new leadership. Cultural Solidarity week kicks off. ECAC [Eastern College Athletic Conference] honors [Pat] Skerry, [Drew] Carleton (men's basketball).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lorin receives light tonight. Week of Commemoration to explore the holocaust.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: [Vice-president Mel] Bernstein hears concerns from key student groups. Tisch library gets additional money. Four finalists will compete for Wendell Phillips award. Depth will be the key for Jumbos (men's tennis). Expectations high for crew (men's crew).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lorin is Tufts' newset light. Groups cooperate for Fling week. Jumbos go 6-4 in up-and-down road travels through the South (baseball). Florida proves to be sunny for softball as team gels (softball).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: E-mail outlawed inside Tisch [Library]. Harry Arlanson, former Tufts football coach dies at 88. Memorial service for poet, Tufts professor. Women take two in Florida [women's Lacrosse]. Rocky start after spring break trip to Colorado [men's lacrosse].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sig Ep [Sigma Phi Epsilon] educates new pledges. Ramble strikes again and again and again.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Deputy Sec. of Treasury discusses crisis in Asia. Biology department given endowed gift for annual research trip to Bahamas. Springfield pride overcomes Jumbos softball squad (softball). First weekend of Crew ends with mixed results (crew). Big Green swamp Jumbos in disappointing home opener (baseball).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: TCUJ [Tufts Community Union Judiciary] to review Senate--'Source' funding conflict. 'Doonesbury' cartoonist to give graduation speech. First ever Arab student week held. Men's Lacrosse lose four straight games. Women remain undefeated five games into strong year (women's lacrosse). Sailing looks to tak top spot.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tufts supports funding of a national environmental group. Men give support to date rape awareness. Marengi, Svencer lead weekend sweep of Bobcats (baseball). Purple Cows tipped as Jumbos controll double-header (softball). 1998 'GAYpril'.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Six left without housing. Newest freshmen to receive letters soon. TCUJ [Tufts Community Union Judiciary] mediates between Source and Senate. Seniors honored with cookies. Buildathon a success. Schnirman announces creation of newly-developed Tufts polls. Burly bear Network roars onto TUTV [Tufts University Television]. Jumbos find their stride to success on home turf (men's track).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Italian Americans address political experience. Friedman captures the Wendell Phillips Award. Senate elections today. Several 'Primary Source' members run for Senate. April Open House coming soon. Both Crews pleased after solid weekend (crew). Freshmen, let your voices be heard: Class of 2001 Senatorial Candidates.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Class of 2001 picks winners. Mayors speak to students. Sadat's daughter and head of Amnesty to speak Tues. Forum held to reconcile gay and Greek communities. Four game week takes its toll (women's lacrosse). Jumbos drop two more games (men's lacrosse).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Changing position of Taiwan topic of professors' discussion. Power outage leaves campus in the dark. Poli-Sci lecturer discusses Plato and Socrates. Balancing families and careers. Softball team splits twin-bills. Huskies defending champs,upend poorly hitting Jumbos (men's baseball). Week of ups and downs for tennis (men's tennis).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Economist cites errors by IMF to solve Asian crisis. Presidential candidates announced at meeting. SNL [Saturday Night Live] comedians to perform. Off-campus housing market is extremely tight for next year. Jumbos' bats frozen during weekend double-header. Spring Fling 98. School of the Museum of Fine Arts and Tufts University: Studio Art Courses, Fall 1998. Senior Fund '98.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Kennedy speaks about UNICCO [University Cleaning Company] controversy. Patents can make money for Tufts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Seniors learn how to eat, drink and dress for success. HEI [Higher Education Initiative] will address University needs. Jumbos run over their compertion (Men's track). Jumbos drop two over the weekend (Men's tennis).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Presidential candidates debate tonight. Finally, [Rapper] L.L. Cool J will be doin' it and doin' it next week. Groups and students receive recognition. Sadat and Schulz lecture on world peace. Five straight losses for Jumbos (baseball). Jumbos last run on the Charles (crew).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Jumbo fest carnival today. EPIIC [Education for Public Inquiry and International Citizenship] brings world together with soccer. Exodus '98 program to celebrate freedom. Kids take on the hill. Tufts students join to combat smoking. Women come up short two times in bouts with Lyons (softball). Women expect a strong year to end (women's lacrosse). Despite making strides, Men's lacrosse continues big losses (men's lacrosse).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: [Jack] Schnirman, [Josh] Goldenberg vie for presidency today. Many sophomores, juniors still lack campus housing. For a day, kids rule. [Matt] Marengi, [Brian] Symmons shut down tough Trinity [baseball] team.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: [Jack] Schnirman Wins Election. Indie rock comes to Tufts tomorrow. Gift to Kerry from Fletcher students deemed too expensive. High School Outreach program held at Tufts over the weekend. [Eric] Ubias: one who does it all. [Harvey] Milk deserves his place in history books. Jumbos [softball] shine over weekend. Tufts [men's track] places second at Colby. Jumbos [men's lacrosse] looking for heart as season ends. Leonard Carmichael Society Connections.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tickets for Senior Week go on sale this week. Spring Fling Line up Re-released. TUPD [Tufts University Police Department] sent mass voice mail for crime prevention. Millennium computer bug will affect Tufts. Women still being paid less than men. Jumbos end slide, win two in a row [men's tennis]. Goalie a very important assest [women's lacrosse].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: New CPC [Career Planning Center] Director appointed. Higher education Initiative sessions. [Zach] Brooks rocks the airwaves. Debate team looks towards the future. Auction raises money for sick children. All new episode of 'Almost Ivy' on TUTV [Tufts University Television]. I put a spell on you [Alvin Ailey Dance Company]. [Matt] Marengi, Jumbos escape, turn aside pesky suffolk [baseball]. Crew covers the entire spectrum in Worcester.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fling Survives the elements, but [rapper] LL [Cool J.] disappoints audience. Candidates exceeded spending limits during recent election. Students contribute to HEI [Higher Education Initiative] symposium. Class fights Asian stereotypes. Rock 'n' Bowl a Success. [Baseball] Seniors shine in home stand. Semester in Review, Spring 1998.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Garry Trudeau to Speak as Commencement '98. Nobel Laureate Professor Allan Cormack dies at 74. No more post-season play for NESCAC [New England Schools and Colleges Athletic Conference] teams. Geology Prof. [Jack] Ridge wins Leibner award. [University President John] DiBiaggio addresses campus issues in May press conference. Retiring Faculty Honored at Meeting. Senate picks next year's leaders. Halogen Lamps Banned from campus. Jack Schnirman outlines vision for Senate and his presidency. CampusLink settles on single plan for '98-'99. Tufts awaiting approval for $9 million fieldhouse. Bookstore, Express, Hotung renovations scheduled to begin in June; Scoops to close. Tufts fullbright scholars to experience the world. [Bryan] Graham is Tufts' first Rhodes scholar in a decade. Seniors Conclude a four-year wild ride. Faculty Members reminisce about their time at Tufts. After Four Years, the class of 1998 has a lot of memories to hold dear. Softball reaches NCAAs for second straight year. Record Setting [Jen] O'Malley finds many ways to succeed. Jumbos [women's lacrosse] fall in ECAC [Eastern College Athletic Conference] semi-finals. Equestrian Team takes second. That Mathey Magic [Kate Mathey. Jumbos [baseball] lose in bid for third straight ECAC [Eastern College Athletic Conference] crown. Eight earn honors at Captain's Lunch. A losing Season for Men's [lacrosse] Team. Four Jumbos Make [Men's Track] Nationals, capping Strong Track Season. Hemingways run on to greater horizons [athlete profile: Rod and Rich Hemingway]. [coach Jim] Watson's First losing Season. Tufts among top ten in ECACs [Eastern College Athletic Conference] [women's track]. Crew looks strong at Nationals. Alumni Weekend: a Roman Holiday! Distinguished Service Awards Honor Five Alums.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: New Class [2002] Betters Predecessors. Incoming Students Matriculate Today. American Students Join in International Orientation. So you're a freshman...where do you go from here? Vet School Offers Open House. Taglienti [Jeff '97] Shining for Sox: Former Jumbo strikes 'em out in minors for Michigan Battle Cats.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tufts falls two more spots in new "US News" rankings. Tufts Student resources to expand its services. Senate lays down plan for new year. PlayFair ends orientation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Run DMC to headline this year's Fall Fest. Student knifed Monday in off-campus stabbing. Dorms [Houston, Richardson, Lewis, Haskell] get major summer renovations. EPIIC (Education for Public Inquiry and International Citizenship) to hold world soccer games. Local green places to go. How to eat your way through Tufts and live to tell about it.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tuesday's Democratic primary, close ten-candidate horse race. Somerville mayor [Mike Capuano] leads in primary for 8th distrrict. Fall Fest cancelled; not enough security. New Tufts club Best Buddies forges new friendships. Performing groups [Pen, Paint, and Pretzels; Sarabande; Torn Ticket II] welcome freshmen. Orientation show [Beelzebubs, Amalgamates, Jackson Jills, and Shir Appeal] highlights a variety of a capella talents. Pen, Paint, and Pretzels succeeds with season opener. Experience should help [men's] soccer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Senate meets, moves past Fall Fest to plan semester. Upgrades required to access new server. Activities fair inaugurates Campus Center. [Jackson] Jills live up to past reputation. Field hockey has high hopes for '98 season.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Somerville's [Mike] Capuano overtakes the eighth [district]. [Paul] Tringale takes over as registrar. College Fest offers plenty of thrills...and free stuff. Four frosh [women's tennis] fill top spots.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Career Services expands into the basement of Tisch Library. Brown and Brew receives top honors [from NACUFS, National Association of College and University Food Services]. Professor [Stephen] Hirsch is recovering steadily from crippling disease [Guillain-Barre Syndrome]. Jewish community celebrates new year. Women['s soccer] knock off first two opponents to open season. Volleyball team takes first four matches to start 4-0.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Senate elections for freshmen Thurs., debate on Wed. night. Peace Corps an option for seniors. The Amalgamates shine with their latest release [Grandma's Camper]. Jumbos [football] to rely on success of offense.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tufts highly ranked in Princeton Review. Veterinary School offers lecture series. Tufts Career Services expands. Taking it [women's cross country] to the next level.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Freshmen debate [senate] election platforms. Political Science requirements altered following recent vote. Non-violence groups [Pan-African Alliance (PAA), Tufts Transgendered Lesbian Gay Bisexual Collective (TTLGBC), Tufts Men against Violence (TMAV), Tufts Feminist Alliance (TFA), Amnesty International, Visions of Tibet, Tufts Democrats, Islamic Society, Southeast Asian Society, AIDS Outreach, Environmental Conscience Outreach (ECO)] to meet [as Coalition of Social Justice and Non-violence]. Last scramble to tour the sights before cold weather. Early success for volleyball. Men's soccer team opens season 1-1. [Men] Golfers swing to strong open. Boston "Reels" at the 14th annual Film Festival.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Campus leaders sound off on Clinton scandal, impeachment. Ten freshmen [Gerardo Alfonso, Tommy Calvert, Benjamin Hayden, David Kim, Jesse Levey, Alethea Pieter, Erin Ross, Michele Shelton, Kristy Tough, Dan Zandman] elected to TCU [Tufts Community Union] Senate. New Catholic chaplain [Father David O'Leary] to teach. GIRLS [Girl Interaction in Raising Levels of Self Esteem] program helps raise local kids' self esteem. Jumbos [women's soccer] say: No goals for you! Slow start [men's cross country], but goals are still riding high.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tufts reassesses campus drinking scene. Peace Games bring Tufts students into community. Led by improved offense, field hockey rolls to 5-0. Many facets of [football] team defeat [Hamilton] Continentals. Jumbos [football] destroy Hamilton in football season opener, 56-30.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: [Vice President of Arts & Sciences Mel] Bernstein reports on the University's state. Faculty pushes authority. Racial issue brought up to TCU [Tufts Community Union] Senate. New looks at Health Services. Disappointing weekend has the [volleyball] squad regrouping.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Vandalism incidents mark first few weeks. Midnight adventure: Porter's up all night. Sailing ranked second in nation. 1998 Japanese animation film festival colors the hub.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Wednesday's forum ["Many Voices, No Community"] draws hundreds of students. Interest in study abroad trips continues to grow with options. Progress made in fieldhouse plans. "Optimus Prime" to debut this year with first issue this Nov. LCS [Leonard Carmichael Society] goes formal. Collegiate Web makes a return with an updated, improved look.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tufts Polls may increase communication between TCU [Tufts Community Union] Senate and student body. Jumbos [field hockey] remain undefeated on season with win over [Bates] Bobcats. Tufts [football] jumps to 2-0 with big weekend win over Bates. Defense [football] steps up big for Tufts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Hotung patio dedication fosters debate over funding. Nobel prize winner [Jose Ramos-Horta] to speak today. Students are the faces of change. Men's soccer rocked by Bates.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Nobel Laureate [Dr. Jose Ramos-Horta] speaks at Tufts, calls for independence in Timor. Fleet Center event [Success 1998]. On following the yellow brick road. Jumbos [women's soccer] win pivotal victory over the Bates Bobcats. New [volleyball] system sees better results. Women [cross country] finish in top five at Babson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Financial aid scrutinized by University members. Career Services expands program. Tufts seniors to perform at Vienna Classic Gala tonight. Golf team comes up short again. Men's crew wins first regatta. Boston's theaters get funky.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Residents satisfied with repairs. Award-winning professor [Gregory Crane] brings history to the masses. "Windows on Research" looks to future expansion. A kid from Jersey, baseball was [Provost Sol] Gittleman's ticket to the world. Mexican American writer Sandra Cisneros recognized in Hispanic Heritage month. Men [cross country] run to victory at Tufts Invitational. [Women's] Tennis team is back over .500.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Republicans thrive on left-wing campus. Annual Coming Out Day unites LGB [Lesbian, Gay, and Bisexual] communities at colleges. Indian diplomat [Mamata Banerjee] to speak today. So you want to be in movies... What's in a name?

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Senate disputes funding with TCUJ [Tufts Community Union Judiciary], "Primary Source". East Hall lounge the site of Coming Out Day activity. With All Stars, everyone an athlete, everyone a winner. Student film [Clotho's Gambit] to be shown tomorrow. Tufts' putters [golf] on par. Women finally beat Bowdoin, now 7-1. Field hockey remains undefeated against Wesleyan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Details of [George] Mitchell's lecture determined. Treasury to increase interest on surplus. Diplomat [Mamata Banerjee] calls for end to corruption. Are universities violating the First Amendment with codes? Theft is on the rise on campus. Volleyball splits the weekend. Tufts [men's cross country] unhappy with second. Beyond the naked quad. Diversity, community, and swing dancing. A Jumbo call to arms. A Tribe calls it quits.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: [Chris] Rogers awarded Professor of the Year in Massachusetts. Campus to play host for Parents Weekend. Nobel Prize winning scientist [Dudley Herschbach] to address campus on Monday. Dalai Lama's brother [Tendzel Choegyal] to speak today. For one student, learning is not just confined to the classroom. Capitalizing on parents weekend. [Bowdoin] Polar Bears outplay Jumbos [men's soccer] in tough second half. [Men's and women's] crew results mixed. The 30-year streak is over with football victory. Women [tennis] snub [Brandeis] Judges.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Exhibit opens to fanfare. Swing dancing: where you can go to practice the latest craze. TUTV adds three new shows to its lineup for this semester. Sailors ranked first in nation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Hillary Clinton to speak in Somerville today. [Vice President for Arts, Sciences, and Technology Mel] Bernstein hers Senate. Jumbos [Men's basketball] lay down the law on the Judges, win 89-77.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Laser cooling lecture proves a hot ticket. Speaker says Talisman Energy complicates confilict in Sudan. [Drew] Carleton leads Jumbos to 7-4 victory over Wildcats. Tufts Society for Creative Anachronism goes medieval. Jumbos [men's basketball] take care of Bowdoin, gear up for ECAC matchup this week. Meeting with Polar Bears leaves Jumbos [Women's basketball] ice cold.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: [Paul] Fridman and [Charles] Needleman elected to Senate. Barney Frank discusses issues on politica and homosexuality. LGBT [Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgendered] Center organizes third annual Safe Colleges Conference. Some students are drinking away their college years. Students take initiative to help indigenous people. Women's squash takes third place in Howe Cup. [Men's] Swimming team pulls together to place fourth at New Englands. [Don] Megerle receives swimming coach of year honor. Jumbos [men's basketball] picked for fourth seed in ECAC tournament. Molly Baker's carrer defined by hard work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: [Robert] Kaplan speaks about Balkans, Caucases. Perfomrance explores topic of masculinity. Hillel's chai week encourages charity. Tufts med school uses grant to educate about organ donation. Jumbos [men's track] run with the big boys. Hockey team faces Fitchburg ub ECAC semi-finals tonight. Four Jumbos receive basketball honors.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tufts democrats play host to mock debate. Jumbos [men's basketball] beat Worcester State, prepare to play on Saturday. [Caitlin] Murphy first in 800 as women run well in regionals. Young swimmers make splash [women's swimming].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Co-ed housing propsal turned down. An activist [Vanessa Kirsch] and an alum returns home. Senate provides students with online voting power. The tale of two cities, and the school between them. Students, faculty meet up for dinner and dcision making. Fencing team finishes fourth place at New England. [men's] Basketball semis at home on Saturday.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tufts students prominent on both sides of Boston [Al] Gore rally. We are the Champions! [men's basketball]. Opening up the classroom discussion to be held Wednesday.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Senate opens dialogue about its constitution. Bill Cosby to speak at commencement. The TUCC's [Tufts University Center for Children] secoind annual children's conference hopes to help local area families through education. Tufts hockey team de-ices its playoff woes. Two Jumbos [Drew Carleton, Dan Mahoney] recieve ECAC honors. Unity carries men's swim team. Squash proves that it is Y2K complaint.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Requirements proposal to be discussed by faculty. Residetial life office releases housing lottery numbers today. Aaron Fererstein, noted philanthropist, to speak. Jumbos [women's basketball] finish with their best record in eight years. patterson runs to NCAAs, but [men's] track team falls short in ECAC's. Equestrian team is ready to start spring.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Somerville mayor [Dorothy] Kelly Gay speaks on town-gown relations, politics, feminism. Battle of the Bands to be held Saturday. Final Vienna Table meeting this Friday. [Alwin] Jones uses his words to make a name for himself on campus. University professor [Dr. Kim Lewis] fighting supergerm. Tufts ballroom dance club continues its growth. Women's track team finishes fourth at EACC Division III's. Despite ppor record, [men's] squash succeeds in rankings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 'New York Times' publisher [Arthur Ochs Sulzberger] comes to campus. Entrepreneur Aaron Feuerstein speaks to the Tufts community. Faculty and students talk about problems. Armenian diplomat [Dr. Arman Kirakossian] to address students on regional conflict. Students voice opinions to faculty. Tufts studetns offer a little bit of 'TLC' to children in local elementary schools. [Dave] Patterson a high-caliber runner. [Women's track coach] Branwen Smith-King, [senior tri-captain Caitlin] Murphy receive NCAA honors. Tufts fencers impressive at championships.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 'Times' publisher Sulzberger discusses values in leadership. Computer problems lead to errors in students' schedules. Armenian ambassador speaks to group of FLetcher students. Joe Deveau band wins battle. Vienna table brings seniors together for final time this year. Men's basketball team surprises, wins 2000 ECAC tournament.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fletcher school dean [John Galvin] to retire. CSL [Committee on student life] calls for TCUJ [Tufts Community Union Judiciary] amendment hearing. IR conference addresses issues concerning Venezuela's future. Cancer support group an outlet for those in need. [Cailtin] Murphy defends National title in the 800-meter run.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Theta Chi pledge injured in altercation at cannon. EPIIC [Education for Public Inquiry and International Citizenship] revives 'Race and Ethnicity' for 2001. Fines put towards financial aid. Robyn Gittleman connects Tufts to the past and future. Student [Elio DeLuca] starts own record label. Talented baseball team looks to overcome its inexperience. Sailing looks to add tropies. [Annmarie] Cholankeril heads to Nationals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Senate organizes airport shuttle. TCUJ [Tufts Community Union Judiciary] gives thumbs up to Paragon after three week debate. Five finalists for Wendall Philips award announced. Lisa Coleman makes herself at home in Capen House. [Men's lacross] Enthusiasm propels lax towards success. Young team [women's lacrosse] looks to repeat '99 success. [Dave] Patterson puts cap on great season. Jumbos [softball] hoping to mix and match way to Regionals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dining Services addresses student concerns in forum. Police prepare to make the big move to Dowling Hall facility. [Frank] Santos casts R-rated 'spells' on students.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Supreme Court issues ruling on use of student activities fees. Senate passes 2000-2001 club budgets. Tufts to award new prize to economists Amartya Sen and John Kenneth Galbraith. Jumbos [baseball] surprise with early win. Softball team goes to Holywood.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Jumbos experience spring break excitement worldwide. Poor attendance forces TSR [Tufts Student Resources] to drop some aerobic classes. On-campus students to get census forms. Women's track team finished strong after an amazing season. Sailing has an up-and-down break. [Men's] tennis team looks to improve on its 1999 showing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Prospective Jumbos recieve acceptance letters. President and Provost reject mixed gender housing plan. Tufts honors world-renowned economists. Tufts veterinary school doctors and students help community. Tufts researcher to appear on NBC's Today Show. [Jon] Zissi nets fourl goals in men's lacrosse teams's 11-9 home victory over Babson. Expectations are high as men's crew prepares for spring season.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: eBay founder, Tufts alum Omidyar gives $10 million. Hank Aaron, other greats, awarded honorary degrees. Fletcher conference to be held this weekend. U.S. Rep. [Michael] Capuano to speak Friday. Gong show set to display 'talented' students. Jumbo's [men's track] hope to spring to top of New England region. Women's track preps for outdoor season. Women's lacrosse breaks headlong into Lyons' den. Freshman can't pin down wrestling club.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Three arrested in 'unlawful assembly' at Latin Way. Search for permanent Dean of Students is narrowed down to four candidates. Tufts in Oz a great success. Spring brings back old-school talent-sharing tradition. Women [lacrosse] escape Bantam menace. Baseball team sweeps a pair of weekend double-headers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: IR program hosts conference on small states. [Keisha] Pollack to speak at graduation. [Michael] Capuano urges responsiveness. Political activist Angela Davis to speak tonight in Cohen. [Branwen] Smith-King will step off track after spring campaign. Men [track] warm up to outdoor season. Jumbos [softball] mamage a split against bridgewater state.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Judiciary rules against cabinet amendment, calls for spring revote. [Denise] Stokes, White House advisor and AIDS victim, addresses students. Tufts teams up with Mystic River group in cleanup. 'Newsweeks' [Matt] Bai, Tufts alum, speaks on journalism. Students find job opportunities in media. Jumbos [men's lacrosse] drop second in a row.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Four to seek TCU [Tufts Community Union] presidential nomination. Holocaust survivor recounts her experience for students. Mexican civil rights activist to speak. African Culture Week brings food, music of Africa to Tufts. Sailing looks to weekend race, [Kimball] Hall looks to Olympics. Despite youth, [women's] crew successful.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tufts and MWRA [Mystic River Watershed Association] collaborate to clean up the Mystic Watershed. Experts examine the state of democracy in South Asia region. Tufts' linraries celenrate the acquisition of millionth book. For writers, the Beat goes on. Tufts helps fund new YMCA facility in Boston. Baseball success continues with double header split. Jumbo's [Men's lacrosse] lose 13-6 in NESCAC competition against Williams.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Former presidential speechwriter Michael Waldman to speak tonight. Senate completes the year with pride in its accomplishments. Senate makes the new 'TCU Meetings' mandatory. Weekend event helpd local kids see joys of reading. Softball team two doubleheaders, now 9-9. [Men's] Tennis team struggles against Williams.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Faculty appears content with current requirements. Senate candidates address key issues. Boston Mayor Menino shares enthusiasm with Tufts students. Men's track team finishes fifth place in Jumbo invitational. Anything bu clear sailing for Jumbos. Jumbo athletes receive academic honors. Women [track] do well despite wind.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Rebecca Walker, a noted feminist and author, visits Tufts. The Roots to headline Fling. TCU [Tufts Community Union] constitution amendments delayed, falls to next Senate. Parents of Peruvian politcal prisoner plead case on campus. 'Jumboboxes.com' a storage site for students, by students. [Mike] Gray to be remembered for his strong work ethic. Conn. College Camels smoke Jumbo men's lax, 15-4. Teamwork, intensity lead to women's firsbee success.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: [David] Moon, [Moira] Poe are chosen as TCU [Tufts Community Union] Senate presidential candidates. Senator Ted Kennedy shares his opinions. Resolving Germany's history. Famed choreographer [Donald] Byrd speaks, presents dance. Daily reporter hists the front lines with Tufts ROTC. Jumbos [baseball] win two out of three over long weekend. Iroguois national lax team spends the wekend at TUfts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: TCUJ [Tufts Community Union] Judiciary revokes recognition of TCF [Tufts Christian Fellowship]. Res Life investigates DEF Jam. Students elect new TCU [Tufts Community Union] reps. .Prospects descend on campus for taste of college. Senior's [James Weinberg] work ethic is quite commendable. Baseball team falls apart down the stretch, drops game in ninth. [women's] Lax drops two NESCAC games.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Online registration launch is successful. New interdisciplinary Middle Eastern studies major created. Science-policy expert [Gordon Orians] to speak today. Students celebrate Passover on and off the Hill. Men [track] come through with strong showing at Jumbo invitational. Jumbos [men's lacrosse] squeak by Colby for overtime win, 7-6.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tufts students join WB/IMF protests in Washington D.C.. TCF [Tufts Christian Fellowship] seeks out legal counsel and plans appeal of J [Judiciary] decision. Women [track] cruise to good finish at the Springfield invitational. [Men's] crew pulling hard despite tough losses. [men's] tennis nets big win over Colby. Jumbo's [softball] sweep the field at the Williams Invitational.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: [Pierre] Omidyar speaks at Tufts, encourages active citizenship. Environmental activist, former Sierra club president, [Adam] Werbach speaks at Tufts. Prof. Dennett to lead panel discussion on technology in Indian culture. Dental school uses technology to make visits far less painful. [Edward] Said reinvents himself. Tufts [women's lacrosse] defeats Camels in rain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bobcat Goldthwait to come for comedy show. Presidential election is today. Poll suggests students know little, care even less about Tufts' student government. UCCPS [University College of Citizenship and Public Service], with grant, aims at long-term goals. Tufts disabilities Awareness Week draws to a close. New exhibit sheds light on aging process. Project Bread's Walk fo Hunger expects to raise millions for local charities. Tufts cyclist pedal to Nationals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: [David] Moon shines in presidential election, defeats Poe. [Bill] Sutherland speaks on activism and history. Tufts students and professors celebrating Secretary's day. Take our Daughters to Work Day to educate girls and boys. Men's track takes second place at Conn. College Invitational. Baseball team contiues to slide. Jumbos [men's lacrosse] ground Falcons for second straight victory. Mixed results for sailing over weekend.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: TCF [Tufts Christian Fellowship] to appeal derecognition to CSL [Committee on Student Life]; hearing date not yet set. Former senator [Alan Simpson] discusses his politics and life expectations. [Robin] Kanarek, other Tufts professors are honored for their work by Senate. Women's track runs circles around its competition. Jumbos [softball] take first in NESCAC. [women's] crew struggles against rivals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fireworks tonight kick-off Spring Fling weekend! Dean [Bruce] Reitman given premanent position. Loews CEO [Jonathan] Tisch at Tufts today. Speakers share the importance of taking a stand on the issues. Celebrating April differentsly. Engineering student [Chris Boullard] takes off with first place for his project. Rusty Jumbo's [men's tennis] fall 5-2 to Bates.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Senate elects general board, ALBO [Allocations Board] chairs. Students enjoy spring fling. Students, administators. discuss diversity. First annual Nia Youth Power Conference held last thursday. Tufts professor [David Elikind] comments on Elian in national media. Tufts softball team cloes out NESCAC schedule with sweep. [Women's] Lacrosse team remains red hot. Baseball takes three out of four on crucial weekend. Jumbos [men's lacrosse] split week of fierce competition. Track teams battle foes at NESCAC finals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Senate elects general board, ALBO [Allocations Board] chairs. Students enjoy spring fling. Students, administators. discuss diversity. First annual Nia Youth Power Conference held last thursday. Tufts professor [David Elikind] comments on Elian in national media. Tufts softball team cloes out NESCAC schedule with sweep. [Women's] Lacrosse team remains red hot. Baseball takes three out of four on crucial weekend. Jumbos [men's lacrosse] split week of fierce competition. Track teams battle foes at NESCAC finals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Class of 2004 welcomed with refurbished campus. Tufts changes alcohol policy. Tufts spends $7 million on summer construction spree. They aim to please: Tufts groups to play orientation. 1999-2000 Jumbo sports at a glance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Save Ferris to headline Saturday's Fall Fest. Tufts suspends Ghana program following sex assaults, rapes. convenience, centralization at heart of student services center. One Jumbo's trash, another's treasure? Turning out to gold [dump and run sale]. Tufts launches new website. More groups [a cappella], more choices. 'Transition year' likely for women's cross country team. Morwick has jumbo shoes to fill [women's cross-country coach].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Internet competition forces bookstore into policy change. Dorm-wide fines removed. Thirty-four professors to join faculty. The Jumbo and teh donkey: making a winning ticket. Students rush to Ex College registration. Fall Fest not a solo show. Save Ferris is 'still cooking'. Fall Fest headliners put out a fun album [Save Ferris]. Women's soccer looks to make championship run this season. Whiting enters sophomore season as Tufts soccer coach [womens]. Men's cross country begins season with gaps to fill. Home field big help for runners [men's cross country].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Save Ferris to the rescue. Rev. 'Scotty' McLennan to leave Tufts in January. Parking policy changes end shortage of residential spots. 'The Observer' Becomes Tufts' weekend newspaper of record. McLennan makes a westward move. Students react to new alcohol policy. Cusick wins Mr. Tufts contest. Fall Fest brings together diverse group of sounds. Jumbos edge out Babson to win season opener; Wesleyan next [women's soccer]. Women's tennis returns strong. Volleyball [women] team puts disappointing season behind. New season brings new challenges for men's soccer. MacGregor [men's soccer] leads a revamped frontline.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: DiBiaggio announces plans to leave Tufts. Judiciary to revisit TCF case [Tufts Christian Fellowship]. New facility will replace rundown Psych. Resource Center [psycology]. A look at President DiBiaggio's accomplishments. School internet is changing work of students, teachers. Music on the move [choir]. Field hockey team returns all of its key elements. Field hockey hopes to continue success of 1999s' late-season run. Unexpected performances help women's cross country. Men finish first, women second at Hayseed Classic [corss country]. Jumbos set sail on season.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ambassador Bosworth is named new Fletcher dean. Eaton, other labs receive impovements. Somerville resident complaints force changes to Davis Square shuttle route. Library web page gets new look. Artists [MFA-Tufts joint degree candidates] offer glimpse into world of anything goes. Field hockey drops season opener to Bentley, 3-2. Jumbos [men's soccer] stomp on Newbury College in season opening. Undefeated Women's soccer takes down Wesleyan at home.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Drunk driver sentenced in alumnus' death. Administrators, students react to stagnant US News ranking. Reconstructed meal plan makes for longer lines at both campus center and Hodgdon. Students no longer have to stick to salad [kosher]. Jumbos [field hockey] fall 1-2 to Middlebury. Women's soccer tops Wesleyan to remain undefeated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Senate and TCUJ [Tufts Community Union Judiciary] candidates square off in election debate. University reinstates Napster with plan to cap use, but network still not up to speed. jumbos get their chance to win a million dollars [game shows]. Jumbos [men's soccer] tie Panthers in overtime in long-anticipated matchup. Cross country [men] disappointing in MIT loss. Women's soccer clawed by Panthers for first loss.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mail Services combines offices with move to Hill. New Marketing Director seeks to increase student interest in foreign study programs. Robert L'H. Miller, retired University Chaplin, professor, dies. Jumpstarting a career after Tufts [Erin Cox in Jumpstart non-profit organization]. Tufts shows Smith some love [women's tennis]. Tufts [women] sails to third-place finish. Golf gets off to swinging start. Volleyball [women] bounces back from a mixed weekend. Women's cross-country team dominates the opposition at Fitchburg State Open. TCU [Tufts Community Union] Judiciary Election: One Seat Open All Classes May Vote.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Seven frosh, one TCUJ [Tufts Community Union Judiciary] member elected amidst ELBO [Elections Board] troubles. New housing office takes on rent crisis. Where's the party? A look at Tufts' dying social scene. Tufts International Orientation. Field hockey bests Wellesley after losing in first two games. Jumbos [football], Cardinals face new offenses in season opener. Minor changes, but still no postseason play for hte Jumbos [football]. Young Jumbos line up against a new-look NESCAC [New England Small College Association]. After the fall of Troy John Troy, football]. Untested Jumbos [football] take field for Saturday's opener. Court rules in favor of Scalia as starter [Todd Scalia, football].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Failed professor search eliminates Hindi/Urdu [language program]. General Colin Powell to speak at Gantcher Center. Jumbos who come to Tufts in Pairs [brothers and sisters together at Tufts]. Creativity defines Tufts' Crafts House. Jumbos [men's soccer] shut out Engineers to keep undefeated record safe. Women's soccer extends its record to 3-1.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Students campaign against controversial Dewick TVs. American Studies program celebrates anniveraries with weekend festival. ROTC cadets receive national award. After American Studies: Alums share experiences. Tufts graduate explores idea of belonging in documentary. TEMS comes to the rescue: Student EMTs quick to respond to emergencies. Tracy Chapman visits unannounced [alumna]. Lionetti nets game winner in double overtime against Colby [field hockey]. Jumbos soccer ties [mens]. Jumbos show inexperience in season opener game [football]. Quaterback issue lingers after game. Men's soccer team to play Amherst Lord Jeffs this coming Wednesday.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Video recorder confiscated from Tisch restroom. Tufts Choice 2000 seeks to get students involved in election. Tufts alum named president of Nasdaq. Ecstasy use on teh rise in clubs and on campus. Jackson Jills shine on new album. Jumbos cement comback on Tooley goal [women's soccer]. Jumbos exact revenge on MIT [men's cross country].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Administration, Senate to hold forum on ailing social scene. Popular computer science course no longer offered (computing on the Internet). Money, logistics slow MOPS [Merchants on Points[ expansion. Dodge dives into women's activism. The affirmative action debate continues. Jumbos only engineer a singe victory at the MIT invitational [women's volleyball]. Sailors dominate in the Hood. Jumbos tack on two W's, but lose out against Williams [women's tennis]. Women's X-country third at Codfish Bowl.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Overloads knock out dorm room power. Proposed music building hits legal and financial roadblocks. Series of hate, sex crimes plague campus. Celebrating an early 21st b-day: Students find their way around rules with fake IDs. Setting that alarm for class not required. Late surge can't stop Amherst [men's soccer]. Field hockey bests Conn. for 2nd win.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: $10 million alumni donation sparks fresh UCCPS [University College of Citizenship and Public Service] initiatives. EPIIC [Education for Public Inquiry and International Citizenship] kicks off its 2000-2001 race and ethnicity program. Reform party leaders fight for prominent role in 2000 election. Bridge-Metcalf program rules undergo significant facelift. Students celebrate holiday at home, or pray with Tufts Hillel. Tufts theater season underway with three shows [The Merry Wives of Windsor, Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?,The Wizard of Oz]. Tufts faces Bates ground attack [football]. Crew anticipates season full of changes. Lindy lands silver medal in World Championships of Crew [men's].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: CTN [College Television Network] executives, student protesters fail to rech concensus on Dewick TV issue. Coupon hoax targets CTN [College Television Network], Dewick. Tufts Choice 2000 to hold debate-watching forum in Hotung. Barreda discusses human rights. Scholars form pannel in order to speak about race. Defense the difference in 12-10 win over Bobcats [football]. Jumbos top Bates, net first conference win [men's soccer].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: New website provides access to information about life at Tufts. Tech. updates improve library's resources. Field hockey drops bates game. Jumbos bounce back with win over Middlebury after tough Williams loss (women's tennis). Jumbos can't top Williams, blame depth for 2nd-place finish at Tufts Invitational [men's cross country]. Jumbos push winning streak to three [women's soccer]. Gehling, Athletic department refocus attention on intramurals, recreation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tufts joins Boston-area protests. TCU [Tufts Community Union] Senate Treasury bank switch to increase interest on the budget surplus. Hotung hot with opinions and election excitement. Larry Harris, the former TCU [Tufts Community Union] president, continues work through United Leaders. TUTV [Tufts University Television] unveils 24 hour programming. Tufts fifth, Crofton second at Tufts Invitational in Grafton [women's cross country]. Golf struggles at NESCAC [New England Small Colleges Association] Championships. Sailing blown out of water at weekend race.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Trustees begin search for new president to replace DiBiaggio. Student sued after June WMFO clash. Campus minimum wage rises. Ice cream for a good cause. Tufts students keep up with the buzz. Jumbos fall to Plymouth State in final minutes of heartbreaker [men' soccer]. Volleyball can't dig competition.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Students, administrators sound off on police handling of parties. Consensus reached on TV controversy. Creativity is key at Arts Haus. Anthony Cornish to leave artis-in-residence post. Defenses have field day ahead in Polar Bears game [football]. Promising results at the Textile Regatta [crew]. Jumbos top Judges for fifth straight win [women's soccer].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Brazilian land reform leader addresses Tufts community. Internet and phone problems frustrate students in Hill Hall. Tufts researchers advance revolutionary technology in effort to clear land mines. Harmonizing between Tufts and NEC [New England Conservatory] students. Prof. Wilson kicks off the Tisch Author Talks. Women's soccer clawed by Bowdoin; dissapointing loss. Late McGraw touchdown leads Jumbos to much-needed victory. Bowdoin Polar Bears defeat Jumbos in a dissapointing loss [men's soccer].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tufts Presses charges against fraternity president. Nationwide search for the next Associate Dean of Students begins amidst changes. System glitch prevents any expansion of Merchants on Points restaurant program. Fletcher trustee's book inspires powerful documentary. Poets snap to the beat at 'Onyx' reading. Tired, hurting Jumbos third at Keene State Invitational [men's cross-country]. Women's tennis team aces both MIT and Bowdoin. Field hockey drops another, loses to Wesleyan 2-1. Volleyball at .500 after spiking two tough NESCAC [New England Small College Association] opponents. Women's X-country can't top Wellesley.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fight for your right to party! Students involved in heated debate about global warming. Seasoned professors Brooke, Trout say goodbye to Tufts. Efforts made to speed up Internet access. Itching for hook-up: Students express concern over STDs. Students find it's not easy eating green. Kimmel speaks on changing gender roles. Yeatman nets last-minute goal for 2-1 Jumbo win [women's soccer]. Men's rugby makes a comeback. Sailing back on top.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Jumbo family reunion: Tufts' Parents Weekend. Students gather on president's lawn, protest police crackdown. Judiciary given second chance to rule on discrimination case. Vigil held for Palestinian, Israeli victims. Students, TTLGBC [Tufts Transgendered Lesbian Gay Bisexual Collective] celebrate Coming Out Day at Tufts rally. Athlete's life is a balancing act [Danielle Cafasso, volleyball]. Off to a good Start [Start House]. Tufts beats Fighting Scots in final minutes of hockey match [field hockey]. Freshman Mikel lets loose on Cardinals [men's soccer].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Official ceremony in Goddard Capel dedicates Dowling Hall. Recurring false fire alarms in Latin Way. Paragon off to strong start, Marxists slow to garner support. Enviosioning a different kind of world for people in third world: Student travels across globe to finght HIV/AIDS spread. Providing a safe haven for people of all orientations. Students gather at Latino poetry reading. YNOTU hit Hotung last Thursday night [band]. Late rally falls short for Jumbos [football].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: TCUJ (TUfts Community Union Judiciary) rules TCF (Tufts Christian Fellowship) violated nondiscrimination policy. Students looking to party off campus. Homecoming distinct from years past. Men's x-country impresses at New England meet. Field hockey evens up record with wins over Gordon, Trinity. Women's soccer team continues strong season by beating Bantams. MacGregor's goal gives Tufts 1-0 win (men's soccer).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Senate selects new student trustee representatives. Trustees deal with issues facing University. Nutritionists receive acclaim for research on vitamins. Student activism spawns from recent TCF [Tufts Chrisian Fellowship] ruling. Tennis team notches sixth straight win [womens]. Jumbos struggle at New England meet [women's cross country]. Sailing team finishes second at Navy Intersectionals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: TCU [Tufts Community Union] Senate repeals mandatory meetings. Economics expert Richard Syron speaks on his storied career, his Tufts education. Senior gaining prestige for her research work in Bosnia. Campus water: Is what we're drinking safe? Sky high housing prices bring student exasperation. Big victories give volleyball team winning record. Tufts rider draws nat'l acclaim [equestrian].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Alumni fueling a booming University development fund. Tufts under federal investigation for grant money misuse. Hate incidents evoke strong reaction from students. Examining the role of trustees. Riding the tech. superhighway. Big anniversaries make Homecoming jumbo-special. Community reacts, reorganizes after TCF [Tufts Community Union] decision. Economics dept. understaffed. Moving to Dowling aids Career Services. Student donations benefit ADL [Anti-Defamation League]. Looking back on a lifetime with student-athletes [Bill Gehling]. T-U-F-T-S! School has a sonorous past. Digital cameras and the 'Right Thing': The Daily talks to director Spike Lee about his latest, 'Bamboozled". Field hockey hopes to tip Cows. Jumbos set for Head of Charles [crew]. Uncertainties loom for two young football teams. Unblemished Ephmen could spell trouble for the Jumbos [men's soccer]. Backfield leads women's soccer. jumbos try to scratch eight-year Homecoming itch [football]. Soccer gears up for Williams [women's soccer].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Students speak out against hate. Students participate in Middle East vigil. Academic Resource Center boasts new comprehensive facilities in Dowling Hall. Lackluster Jumbos show little spirit at Homecoming [football]. Freshman Hackett has his way with Jumbo defense [football]. Four teams are tied for first in NESCAC [New England Small College Association]. Tufts silences Williams, 2-0 [women's soccer]. Jumbos can't milk the Cows, fall 21-10 [football]. Williams knocks off men's soccer 2-1.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Community calls for administration to take action against discrimination. New plan has mixed effects on club sports. New system allows facilities requests to be submitted online. Judicial procedures under scrutiny after Brandeis case. A 'Merry' time in the Arena [Drama department at Balch Arena Theater]. Field hockey ousts Ephs. Women's team heads up performance on Charles [crew].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Behind the scenes: Authors are displeased with the movie adaptations of their books. Hey Mr. DJ: Pass me the mic and spin the records: uncovering Tufts' underground hip-hop culture of djs, emcees, and dancers. MacGregor nets a goal and an assist as Jumbos defeat Gordon [men's soccer]. Jumbo tennis secures third at New England Championships [womens]. Volleyball team has mixed results. Jumbos top Bates in first round of NESCAC [New England Small Colleges Association] playoffs [women's soccer]. Quiet weekend means smooth sailing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Despite progress in numbers, racial diversity still an issue. Lack of professors, large classes plague Spanish program. New location allows program to expand. Cliquing across color lines. Women's rugby team breaking sterotypes - and a leg or two. Field hockey team advances to Saturday semifinal. Golfers struggle at New Englands, finish 35th overall.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Omidyars awarded the 'Light on the Hill' alumni accolade. Low costs key to implementing three new majors to curriculum. Heated debate about cooling the planet. Just how liberal can we go? African-American art exhibit at Tufts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Minority high school students participate in Tufts' admissions outreach program. Annual Halloween onthe Hill a success. Gore, Bush in dead heat; Tufts profs analyze election. Pre-med students must work hard to make the grade. Former 'Observer' Editor-in-Chief-turned 'New York Times' writer shares his experiences. 'Merry Wives' is merry both in and outside of the bedroom [Balch Arena Theater]. Ineffective offense leads to 8-0 shutout of football by Amherst. Women's soccer falls to Middlebury in NESCAC [New England Small Colleges Association] finals. Field hockey loses to Bowdoin 2-1 in semis.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Change to block schedule format unlikely, despite complaints. Woburn resident expands charges filed against Tufts students in WMFO lawsuit. Asian-American month activities aim to increase unity, visibility of culture groups. Queer women discuss fear and insecurity on campus. Men's soccer earns first-ever NESCAC [New England Small College's Association] bid after weekend win. Limping x-country squad falls at NESCACs [New England Small College's Associaion]. Volleyball heads into NESCAC [New England Small College's Association] tournament.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Beelzebubs to sing at Celtics opener. Drucker seeks last career highlight [David Drucker men's soccer]. Sailors fare well in last weekend's regattas. Playoff Wednesday at Tufts [women's soccer, fieldhockey]. Late goal sinks soccer team [men's]. Women's cross country finishes seventh in NESCAC [New England Small Colleges Association]. Team reaches for ultimate goal [Frisbee].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: General Colin Powell to speak at Gantcher today. Faculty subcommittee proposes 'Professors of Practice' post. Renovations to lab yet to be completed. Upperclassmen and freshman bond in Explorations. Students seek to make money off the hill. Bobcats fall prey to Tufts [women's field hockey]. Jumbos stomp New England in first round of NCAA tourney [National Collegiate Athletic Association, women's soccer]. Four Jumbos awarded NESCAC honors for women's soccer [New England Small Colleges Association, Sara Yeatman, Randee McArdle, Carmen Mikacenic, Jess Trombly].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gen. Powell recounts Cold War Tensions. Senior benefit from marked rise in recruiting on campus. TCU Rap Off raises mo' money [Tufts Community Union]. Infestations bugging students. Keeping up with the club scene. Seniors to play final game at Zimman Field Saturday [football]. Cruz takes Tufts cross country by storm [J.R. Cruz]. Tennis slams its way to 9-1 campaign [women].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Senator Kerry to host Gore-Liberman rally at Tufts. Going from studies to skydiving. Shir Appeal's new album is more than up to par. Tufts loses to White Mules [football]. 17 Seniors played final home game [football]. Women's soccer advances to NCAA Quarterfinals [National Collegiate Athletic Association]. Field Hockey drops nail-biter in ECAC, 1-0 [East Coast Athletic Conference].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Comedian Jay Mohr to headline fall Comedy Show. A Friday on the other side: A Cruise down frat row with the TUPD [Tufts University Police Department]. Searching for a special someone: Students hook-up, but rarely pursue relationships. Local band plays Hotung tonight on way to stardom [Angry Salad]. Jumbos 'Cruz' to victory at ECAC finals [men's soccer, J.R. Cruz, East Coast Athletic Conference]. Volleyball team grabs 6th place in NESCAC after tourney split [New England Small Colleges Association]. Three field hockey players named All-NESCAC [Collette Gaudet, Lindsay Lionetti, Amy Polverini].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sen. John Kerry leads Gore rally at Tufts. Athletics help bridge racial gaps. In Living Color: Race on the hill, Africans and African Americans: Do shared historical roots mean common cultural ground? Women's cross country squad finishes 12th at Div. III ECAC championships [Eastern College Athletic Conference]. Soccer captain has high aspirations for team [women]. Babson first up for men's soccer. Tufts prepares for NCAA Quarterfinals [women's soccer, National Collegiate Athletic Association].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Political science course fosters cross-ocean, international dialogue on African issues. Work study offers Tufts students range of options. Spanish Civil War vet speaks [Abraham Osheroff]. Tufts skins Babson Beavers, advances to ECAC semifinals [men's soccer, Eastern Collegiate Althletic Conference]. Jumbos finish up respectable season [field hockey].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Trustee's donation to expand engineering leadership skills. Fast to end world hunger. Diving under the sea on the silver screen: Biologist speaks on mystery of life below the Galapagos Islands [Dr. Carole Baldwin]. Painting by numbers: Famed muralist visits Tufts, talks about art with Explorations class [Gary Rickson]. Panthers too much for Tufts Jumbos in season-ending loss [football]. Underdog Jumbos win first ever ECAC championship versus Bowdoin [Eastern Collegiate Athletic Conference].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Safety escort service hires student guards. Survey says: 'Tufts polls' still not up after nearly three years. New program expands life-long learning opportunities. Tufts to host its first-ever NCAA semifinal contest [National Collegiate Athletic Association]. Injuries, inexperience prove too much to overcome [football]. Jumbos heading back to National Championships [men's cross country]. Leslie Crofton goes to Washington [women's cross country].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Campuslink future uncertain as Tufts explores other options. Difficulty of retaining faculty of color continues. Tufts behind in merchandizing name, logo. Campus vs. culture?: Students strive to balance two worlds in the States. Improved men's squash to start season this week.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fight to strengthen nondiscrimination policy continues. Off-campus rents on the rise. Panelists talk about faith and orientation. Senate to provide easy route to airport. Marijuana mayhem: drug use on the rist nationwide: Students talk about the highs, lows, and consequences of smoking pot on campus. Fencing strong after rebuilding. Sailing team wraps up season well, but without championships. New season gives Jumbos one last shot at ECAC glory [Eastern Collegiate Athletic Conference]. For Jumbo success, key lies in defense [hockey]. Jumbos benefit from one of conference's best defenders [hockey]. Hockey looking to match 1999 sucess. Men's swimming returns key performers, should start strong. Tufts student-athletes: 'dumb jocks' or smather thean the rest?

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tufts extends its suspension of Ghana program through spring. SIS Online snafus complicate student registration process. Students, administrators developing plans to build a new dorm on Medford campus. The perfect college internship: Students share their real-world, working experiences. A look at the NCAA final four [National Collegiate Athletic Association, women's soccer]. Tufts to host its first Final Four tomorrow [women's soccer]. Young men's soccer team put together a successful season. Squash team hopes to improve on 19th.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Final Four fanfare ends in dramatic NCAA finish [National Collegiate Athletic Association]. Mail room implements Saturday deliveries. Lights, camera, action for Tufts alumni. Sampling of Tufts in TV. A cappella takes its show on the road [Belzebubs]. Jay Mohr headlines Fall Comedy Show. Cross country teams race to success at Nationals in Wash. Finals play puts exclamation point on super season. [women's soccer].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Women's swimming and diving team looks to number advantage. Gaudet [Colette] and Polverini [Amy] named field hockey All-Americans.

ELBO desperate for members [Election Board]. Swimmers fare well in openers. Senior and softmore brothers are a force on the football field [Everett and Andy Dickerson].

Students express discontent at School of Americas. Record-breaking season will be tough to repeat [women's soccer]. Hockey takes home the Coca-cola Classic trophy. Men's squash starts season 4-1.

Committee after committee try to tackle campus race issues. Minorities and the Greek System. 2000 Basketball Preview [Men and Women's]. Goodman, Shapiro primed to lead Tufts basketball [Brian Shapiro, Emily Goodman]. JV team give freshmen a chance [Basketball]. Fresh faces could spark teams [Men's and Women's Basketball. Season begins, but where have all the players gone [Women's Basketball]? Jumbos not at a loss for offense [Men's Basketball]. Defending ECAC champs return proven, talented core [Men's Basketball, Eastern Collegiate Athletic Conference]. Women's basketball kicks off season with obstacles in way. Jumbos batter Rams [Men's Basketball]. Injury-ridden women's team falls to Babson [Basketball].

Inside a protest: sitting in and around Bendetson. Protesting the protest. Squash rolls to third straight win. Freshman set to lead Men's track. Women's track team to kick off season under new leadership.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Going to class without leaving the comfort of your bedroom? Tufts student groups organize AIDS Awareness Week activities. Jumbos stomp St. Mike's, 7-2 [men's hockey]. Jumbos tread water; take dive in opener [women's swimming]. Rugby [men's]team completes perfect club season, 2-0 in postseason.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Impact of president's statement on TCF constitution uncertain [Tufts Christian Fellowship]. Speaker warns students of HIV/AIDS risk. Students pleased with improved network performance in dorms. Teaching television hands-on Freshman Explorations class travels to New York City for a first-hand lesson in the media. Tufts prof receives big break form Oprah [Andre Dubus III]. Jumbos improves record with stomp on Springfield's Pride [men's basketball]. Christoudias explodes in second half of Jumbos shut down Lasell [women's basketball].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Fencing cannot foil competition. Promising exhibition meet for men's track.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Studends and faculty debate role of race in everyday life. Freshman lead swimmers into break undefeated [men's swimming]. Eight Jumbos qualify for post-season in first meet [women's track]. Tufts has final answer for Regis [women's basketball]. Squash overmatched by Brown, Trinity [men's].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Shapiro's three at buzzer dams Beavers [men's basketball]. Squassh maintains high ranking despite mediocre week [women's]. TDC [Tufts Dance Collective] winter show comes to Jackson.

Tufts student investors uneasy with stock market volatility. Students debate going to Israel. Students tied of election 2000. Hockey salvages win with third period scoring burst. Hockey team gets national mention.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Grant will allow TUTV [Tufts University Television] to expand. Tufts students get flu-shots despite nation-wide shortage. Disciplinary panel ruling says DJ firing did not violate policy. Two wreaths stolen from President's house last week. Celebrating Ramadan. Disciplining the protesters. Get a head start on your winter reading. Getting the lowdown on the workings of the Senate. Jumbos trample the Bison 9-2 [hockey]. Busy weekend for basketball programs [men's and women's]. TCUJ [Tufts Community Union Judiciary] rules that TCF [Tufts Christian Fellowship] violated policy. 20 sit-in at Admissions to demand administrative redress. DiBaggio to leave Tufts, committee formed to find replacement. Women's soccer team finishes second in NCAA [National Collegiate Athletic Assocation] tournament. Students get involved with presidential election. Students succeed in campaign against Dewick TVs. Opening of Dowling Hall improves student services. Tufts suspends Ghana program for fall, spring semesters after violent rape. Powell speaks on Cold War, children during speech in Gantcher. social scene changes drastically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains issues of the Tufts Daily, the student newspaper of Tufts University.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Y2K bug delays grade availability. Student Services website helps Jumbos carpool. Boston basics: Find your way off the Hill. The US loses its war on drugs (Traffic review). 'House of Mirth' true to novel. No conflict of interest for Powell at Tufts. Women's basketball survives early woes to defeat Brandeis. Boudrow's prowess powers Jumbos. Whiting, Yetman receive honors. Jumbos lose momentum, fall 9-2 after two losses. Tufts wins tourney in Bahamas. Giants, Ravens make surprise Super Bowl entrances with wins.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

'Before Night Falls' showcases Cuban artist's struggle. Women's basketball falters in second half, loses to Engineers. Basketball to open NESCAC [New England Schools and Colleges Athletic Conference] play against Bates Bobcats tomorrow. Track teams get out of block quickly. Jumbos go undefeated over break. Men's basketball tops Wheaton, Brandeis. Beavers hand Jumbos second loss of the season.

News from Tufts' Graduate schools: New certificate programs created in bioengineering, computer science, Medical and Dental Schools to train people from United Arab Emirates, Chairs endowed at Fletcher and Dental Schools. Retired professor Badau is back for more. Coming back to the real world. Comedies, tragedies, and maybe a vagina, Tufts' theater season in a nutshell. Winter Week offers songs, sumos, and soroities - all on campus. Through the cracks: Gore's failures, Bush's successes. Musicians need a home at Tufts. Questioning the news. Women's basketball falls to Bates in NESCAC [New England Schools and Colleges Athletic Conference] opener. Women look to avoid third straight loss. Men's swimming remains undefeated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Trios, now take-out, overhauls its menu. Eaton renovations nearly complete. BU [Boston University] rape case awaits trial verdict. Tufts alumnus elected as Council president, second Black to hold post. Murphy looks toward the heavens, Student shares celestial experience with Ex College class. Tufts orchestra goes tropical. New black women's group hopes to be reliable place for discussion. Jumbos get their win well 'Dunn', Sophomore's clutch free throw help scorch Clark. Hockey falls to Worcester State for first conference loss. Men's track team coasts to victory at Tufts Invitational. Women's track breezes to win. Women's swimming has busy weekend, Jumbos defeat Trinity, Wesleyan. No Grade for You. Goodbye, Mr. Jefferson. A Prize First Step for Korea. A Missed Opportunity. A Peaceful View for a War Zone.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Mayor launches re-election bid, Kelly Gay launches campaign for second term. Harshbarger encourages political participation. An outside look at American politics, International students talk about the US system. Archives grant takes research to a new level on the Web. Beekzebubs host a regional a cappella quarterfinals. Men split weekend doubleheader, Jumbos edge Trinity in comeback, lose to Amherst. Guards go high, low in up and down weekend, Tufts misses Shapiro's scoring punch. Women's basketball splits pair of NESCAC [New England Schools and Colleges Athletic Conference] games over weekend, Team falls to Amherst after win over Trinity. Hockey breezes by Lebanon Valley, Jumbs bounce back after first conference loss. Bowdoin, Colby separate themselves from rest of NESCAC [New England Schools and Colleges Athletic Conference].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Hindi/Urdu course returns to Ex College. Two profs killed at home near Dartmouth. Akouk will serve 40-45 years for BU [Boston University] rape. New psychology building to bring unity, research space for dept. Grad School News: First ever Research and Graduate Study Fair. Dental School opens simulation clinic, Vet School conducts study on animal hoarding. Looking at Greek Life. Rushing into the Greek Scene, Students decide whether to join frats and sororities. Forming a sisterhood, Sororities focus on boosting numbers, having fun this rush season. With win, men's swimming continues its perfect season. Runners take second at tough Bowdin meet. A Tufts without Greeks, a college without fun. A change of heart. Sororities: see for yourself. Go for the green! To pledge or not to pledge. The unmerited reputation of Zeta Psi.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Tufts contines efforts to cut global warming. Professors in the News: Child developmentt expert speaks out against weekend schooling, Author and Tufts lecturer Andre Dubus III appears on Oprah, Education professor doubts value of online tests. Women chan(g)e face of engineering, School of Engineering touts large female population. Fencing in Tufts, Administration plans to extend iron fence around most of campus. Bernstein addresses International House. Exorcising my a capella demons. TCI must publicize within the Tufts Community. Men's track races to third at Bowdoin Invitational, Jumbos finish behind Springfield College, Bowdoin. Bates out-treads Tufts in close showdown. Squash slams Fordham. Fencing defeats three of four, Three team members qualify for Junior Olympics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Celebrating Black History Month, Films and lectures recognize a history long ignored. Inside our judicial branch, Recognizing groups and mediating conflict. Far from home, now searching for comfort in a duvet, Abroad student adjusts to her new life in London, getting acclimated slowly but surely. Hockey team loses to UMass-Boston, falles to 4-4 in 2001. Competition in ECAC [Eastern College Athletic Conference] Northeast is so hot, it can melt ice [hockey]. Women's basketball stuffs Gordon. NESCAC [New England Schools and Colleges Athletic Conference] weekend could be turning point of season. Tolerance. Mismanagement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Spring Jazz Show to feature Charlie Hunter and John Scofield. Tufts-China exchange opens cross-cultural doors. Omidyar Scholarship recipients reach out to community. Ski team plows way to upper echelon of division. Jumbos prey on the Owls for 82-73 win, Shapiro returns, Van Natta scores. Rematch of ECAC [Eastern College Athletic Conference] title game tonight at Cousens, Men's basketball looks to defeat Colby tonight, Bowdoin tomorrow. Women's squash bounces through up and down season, Young team tops Wellesley, but loses to tough Dartmouth squad.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Finalists for Wendell Phillips chosen by CSL [Committee on Student Life]. Symposium panelists share perspectives on Chinese culture. Rising to the top of the world, Lecturer recounts long road to success on Oprah. A 'warm' welcome back to Tufts, Winter Week gives Jumbos more social alternatives. Paradise or bust. Men's basketball splits weekend, Jumbos overcome ten-point deficit to defeat Bowdoin. Hockey nets first shutout of season, Jumbos stampede overwhelmed Falcon team 7-0. Jumbos halt curse against Fitchburg St. Jumbos trip vs. NESCAC [Northeast Association of Schools and Colleges] foes, Poor shooting slows women against Colby, Bowdoin. Can Tufts rebound, save season?, Women's basketball in dire straits after weekend losses. Two comebacks, one win, Jumbos beat Bowdoin, fall to Colby.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Professors in the News: Philosophy professor skeptical of animal consciousness, professor of nutrition reveals findings on Vitamin A, Music professors' talents acknowledged by Globe. 'Simpsons' fans find home, New No Homers Club meets with enthusiasm. Searching for culture in the Garden State. Tufts athletics sparking students' interest once again. Men's basketball shoots for charity, MacMannis wins free throw contest in fundraiser. Mt. Holyoke Invite easy as 1-2-3 for Tufts. Men's track slowed at Tufts Invitational, ends up fourth.

LCS [Leonard Carmichael Society] blood drive a success despite weather, illness. Trustees take responsibility for big decisions, seek little input. Some Jazz, a little hip-hop and a Spring Fling, Concert Board brings popular bands to music fans up and downhill. Hate groups prosper on American soil, Documentary gives human face to American hate groups. Seven questions with Marissa Simonelli. Ski teams plow over competition. Boucher continues to ice competition on Tufts ski team. Jumbos can't get over hump, defeated by Camels. Distance running a lifetime study for Smith. Good luck, Ariel Sharon. Ariel Sharon - too laden with blood to fly with dove's wings. Thinking across boundaries. Scheduling block. The Bush Administration: An environmental hazard. Weather envy. Save our house. You are whatever you say you are.

Kofi Annan to speak at Fletcher, UN head to give school's commencement remarks. Residential Life ends fall-only housing lottery. Rebuilding after a disaster, Students organize earthquake relief. Tufts guitarist is finger-picking good. TSO [Tufts Student Orchestra]: Better music culture than Hotung, Don't let a symphony orchestra on campus pass unnoticed. Trustees should consider approving 150-bed dorm. Sharon's victory a blow to peace process. Men's basketball to face Ephs, Panthers on the road this weekend. Keeping the hall intact, RAs must strike a difficult balance. Afro-Cuban jazz ensemble has rythm pulsing at Cohen. Zydeco accordion to Buckwheat, Musician strive to create intergenerational tunes. Jazz show rocks Cohen. Faulty reasoning. Women's basketball splits weekend games, Chances for NESCAC [New England Schools and Colleges Athletic Conference] berth improve. Wesleyan match will be a must win. February madness grips NESCAC [New England Schools and Colleges Athletic Conference], Conference competition heats up before final games. Tough week ahead for hockey team.

A match made.... legally. Spotlight on John Scofield, Berklee grad brings jazz-rock hybrid to Cohen. Sex, death, and... sand? Men's squash defeats MIT, ends 6-year losing streak against rival. Women speed into postseason, Crofton qualifies for Nationals, Deeb shatters team record in 600-meter race. Bobcats squash Jumbos 8-1, exploit home-court advantage. Unparalleled. Hussein is no reason to maintain sanctions on Iraq. A tax cut is great, but.... A new dialogue concerning the death penalty. Whose university?

Professors in the News: Tufts professor stresses the importance of civic participation, Teeth-grinding a common stress related disorder, says Tufts expert, Researchers continue quest for genetic roots of autism. How Tufts' foreign language department measures up. A different kind of V-Day for students, 'The Vagina Monologues' puts Valentine's Day on hold. Christmas in February. The woman behind the vagina. 'Bos know baseball (and basketball, and football), Sophomore roomates Brian Shapiro and Evan Zupancic are two-sport stars for Tufts. Girivin hopes to leave with a splash. Japha sits, Edinburgh soars to playoffs.

scopecontent.p: Spring Fling successful despite an unfamiliar moe. as headline band; Online elections get rave reviews; Chi O apoligizes after prank poster incident; 32 alum reps selected; Mix business and pleasure: Delta Sigma Pi fraternity; Summer: more time to cook; TCCS [Tufts computing and communcations services] will upgrade connections; Student reaction to block schedule mixed; Concert-ghoers enjoy Mobb Deep's set more than headliner moe; Hyping up in Cohen; The demon barber of BRattle St.; A year of milestones: University celebrates new president, 150th birthday; Jamshed Bharucha named new provost; Tufts joins Brown, Columbia in calls for graduate union; Carson elected president, culture rep vote remains; Fall Fest may be cancelled due to budgeting errors; Clinton speaks on Mideast; Capen Blaze destroys two houses; Incidents of hate plague campus; Students, faculty push to diversify curriculum; Omidyars speak at commencement; Baseball sweeps Colby to win best in NESCAC East; Men's lax [lacrosse] beats Connecticut college.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 2,300 to recieve degress today; Tufts examines culture studies in curriculum; Candidates talk, raise funds at Tufts; Student duo gets help from Tufts to form video production company; A tale of two presidents; Four seniors elected by peers to serve on Alumni Council; Relations with Medford and Somerville are on upswing; Dorm improvements part of summer plans; Senate in-house elections reheld; CSL [Committee on student life] rules on Halpern, 'Source' case; Adminstrators travel to spread Tufts name; Gittleman reflects on university's past, present, future; Small changes in Jumbo lifestyle; Accomplished individuals to grace graduation platform; Tufts' class of 1952; Tufts' history class addes to Ex College's repertoire; Senior publishes poetry book [Alwin Jones]; Accomplished seniors honored; Class studies slavery in Medford; Arts on the hill 2001-02; Beelzebubs, alimni release lates live album, 'Punch'; 'Can I tell you a lot of Stuffis?' Alum's band hits the touring scene [Josh Klein A2001]; Several a cappella groups to put out albums in the fall; 150 years of light on the hill; Did you know? Fun facts about the history of Tufts; The rise and fall of the sesquicentennial class; Baseball: NESCAC championships; Softball's fabulous four wraps up successful era, won't be forgotten; Women's lax misses playoffs [la crosse]; Men's lacrosse falls to Jeffs in first round of NESCACs; Sailing team concludes regular season, prepares for Nationals; Women's track second at NESCACs; Track and field team experiences success; Sports year in review.
